Detailed Description

Iterative implementation of the quicksort algorithm for one-dimensional arrays with support of index arrays.

#define myRandom ( num   )     ( rand() % ( num ) )

Returns a random number between 0 and num - 1.

This preprocessor operation is only defined, if the pivot flag is set.

Parameters:
num defines the upper bound for the returned random number
Returns:

Definition at line 107 of file ArraySort.h.

#define pivot ( L,
R   )     ( L + myRandom( R - L ) )

Returns a pivot value as random number between L and R - 1.

The pivot value is only set as random value if the pivot flag above is set.
The pivot value is used for the partitioning step of the quicksort algorithm implementation in function sort.

Parameters:
L defines the lower bound for the returned random number
R defines the upper bound for the returned random number
Returns:
a pivot value between L and R - 1
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1995

Definition at line 135 of file ArraySort.h.

Referenced by sort(), and sort2DBy1st().

#define PIVOT

If this flag is defined, then a pivot value is determined by random.

Otherwise it is determined by bit operations.

Definition at line 82 of file ArraySort.h.

Function Documentation

template<class T>
void sort ( Array< T > &  value,
Array< unsigned > &  index 
)

Performs a quicksort on the one-dimensional array "value" and will also return the index array "index" of "value".

This method implements the famous quicksort algorithm not in a recursive but in an iterative way.
Furthermore an index array is returned, corresponding to the elements of the value array in their original order and sorted in the same way as the values of the value array. This index array can be used especially for the functions "ArrayIndex operator&&(ArrayIndex& a, ArrayIndex& b)" and "ArrayIndex operator||(ArrayIndex& a, ArrayIndex& b)".
By defining/undefining the flag pivot, it can be determined, whether the initial pivot point for the first partition step is a random value or a value calculated by bit operations.

Parameters:
value the one-dimensional array with the values that will be sorted. After the method call, the values in this array are in ascending order
index will contain the indices of the elements of array value as given before sorting and in the same order as the corresponding elements in value after the sort
Returns:
none
Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1995
Changes
none
Status
stable

Definition at line 208 of file ArraySort.h.

References Array< T >::elem(), ArrayBase::nelem(), pivot, and ArrayBase::resize().

void sort2DBy1st ( Array< double > &  value  ) 

Performs a quicksort on the rows of the two-dimensional array "value" by the values of the first column.

This method implements the famous quicksort algorithm not in a recursive but in an iterative way.
The sorting is performed by the values of the first column. All elements of the second column are sorted in the same way as the corresponding values of the first column belonging to the same row.
By defining/undefining the flag pivot, it can be determined, whether the initial pivot point for the first partition step is a random value or a value calculated by bit operations.

Parameters:
value the two-dimensional array with the values that will be sorted. After the method call, the values of the first column of this array are in ascending order
Returns:
none
Author:
C. Igel
Date:
2005
Changes
none
Status
stable
